journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part A: Journal of Power and Energy

title-group.article-title: Effect of axially non-uniform rotor tip clearance on aerodynamic performance of an unshrouded axial turbine

article-meta.aff: College of Power and Energy Engineering, Harbin Engineering University, Harbin, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: *College of Power and Energy Engineering, Harbin Engineering University, Harbin 150001, People’s Republic of China. email: zhengqun@hrbeu.edu.cn

abstract.p: Tip leakage flow is responsible for a significant amount of aerodynamic losses in a turbine stage, and the mixing of leakage flow with the rotor passage secondary flow causes losses and reduces turbine stage efficiency. This article presents a numerical investigation of the effect of axially non-uniform tip clearance on the aerodynamic performance of an unshrouded axial turbine at design and off-design conditions, in an attempt to seek an optimal tip clearance chordwise distribution to control the interaction between tip leakage and passage secondary flows, and then reduce the total losses in turbines. Different types of axially uniform and non-uniform rotor tip clearances were used in this investigation, which include uniform, expanding, shrinking, and back- and front-step tip clearances. Numerical results show that, for the axially uniform tip clearances, the interaction mechanism between tip leakage and passage secondary flows is different in the relatively small and large tip clearance heights. With the tip clearance height gradually increasing, tip passage vortex at the passage exit is first enhanced, and then it becomes weak. Axially non-uniform tip clearance changes the chordwise distribution of over tip leakage mass flow. The front-step and shrink tip clearances are able to efficiently utilize the interaction of tip leakage flow with passage secondary flows, and then reduce the total losses in turbines. For different axially non-uniform tip clearances, loading distribution near the tip has a great impact on the tip leakage flow. It will result in great losses when the maximum tip clearance and loading positions are in the same position along the blade.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Tip leakage flow is one of the most prevalent andinfluential features of the flow through turbinerotors, which is responsible for a number of adverse effects [1]. These significant effects include the blockage of the passage flow, unsteadiness in the downstream blade passage, complexities in tip heat transfer, and aerodynamic losses associated with the resulting secondary flows. Schaub et al. [2] found that as much as one-third of the losses in a turbine stage could be attributed to the tip leakage flow. Therefore, the investigation of tip leakage flow is very important for the improvement of the turbine stage performance.

The basic work with respect to the developmentofthe tip leakage flow was published by Lakshminarayana in 1970 [3]. Booth [4] and Sjolander [5] presented comprehensive reviews of various effects of the tip leakage flow. With better understanding of the tip leakage flow, many loss prediction methods have been proposed by Lakshminarayana [3], Yaras and Sjolander [6], and Denton [7, 8]. The loss development within the passage due to the tip leakage flow was investigated in cascades by Bindon [9], and Yaras and Sjolander [6]. The majority of the loss is due to the interaction between tip leakage and passage secondary flows. Furthermore, the interaction has been investigated in detail by means of experiments by Yamamoto [10] and Chan et al. [11]. The results have shown that there is a strong interaction between tip leakage and passage vortexes.

All these works are aimed at understanding the effects of tip leakage flow for the purpose of improving the turbine stage performance. It is clear that the secondary flow in the rotor passage plays a very important role in the total losses of the turbine, and the direction of tip leakage flow is opposite to that of the secondary flows inside the rotor blade passage. Therefore, efficiently controlling the interaction between tip leakage and passage vortexes to reduce losses may be a way of improving the turbine stage performance. However, most blade tip designs do not seek to reduce the main leakage losses through detailed manipulations of the interacting flows and structures, but instead take the more straightforward approach of simply reducing the tip leakage flow such as squealer tip, and blade tip bowing.

The squealer tip is the most prevalent design in practice today within high pressure turbines. The squealers impose additional resistance to the leakage flow path, and are effective in reducing both the leakage flow and tip heat transfer. The use of squealer tip for reducing the tip leakage flowrate and losses has been reported by several researchers in various aspects (Mischo et al. [12], Ameri et al. [13], and Prakash et al. [14]).

The loading around an airfoil tip section is the main driver for tip leakage flows. DeCecco et al. [15] and Yamamoto et al. [16] originally suggested off-loading the tip to reduce the tip leakage flow. Staubach et al. [17] achieved this by tangentially bowing the rotor thus applying a radial body force towards the casing, moving passage mass flow away from the tip. The tip loss exchange rate was reduced by 40 per cent. In addition, Shao et al. [18] made a theoretical investigation on the effects of blade tip loading and tip clearance chordwise distributions on the tip leakage mixing loss of compressor blades. Parameter studies showed that tip leakage mixing loss is directly proportional to blade tip loading level, and influenced by blade tip loading distribution. Moreover, the position of the maximum tip clearance and centre of blade loading distribution should be organized at different locations along the blade; otherwise, it will lead to great losses.

Axial non-uniform tip clearance concept was first proposed in a compressor by Mohan and Guruprasad [19] in 1994, and then has been investigated in detail in various aspects (Shao et al. [18], Wang et al. [20], and Ma and Li [21]). The concept is based on the advantages of a smaller tip clearance in the front portion of the blade and a larger clearance in the rear portion, which allows a higher tip leakage flowto interact with the passage secondary flow, casing wall boundary layer, separated flow on the blade suction surface, and the scraping vortex, which are more prominent at the rear portion of the blade. Nonetheless, it is not known whether this concept is valid for turbine flow. In turbines, blade tip provides the rotating–stationary interface for the contained working fluid, and it is commonly at leastpartially damaged or worn in the course of operation. Therefore, blade tip material may be lost or deformed, generally leading to the non-uniform damage or material loss. The non-uniform change in tip geometry will alter the aerodynamics, usually leading to accelerated loss. However, Qi et al. [22] developed a simulation and optimization platform, and investigated the tip clearance shape’s effect on the efficiency of aero-engine turbine. The results showed that the numerical results agreed well with experiment data, and the isentropic efficiency was improved 0.395 per cent with the optimized tip clearance shape.

The numerical investigation presented in this article further explored the application of axially non-uniform tip clearance concept in turbines in an attempt to seek an optimal tip clearance chordwise distribution to efficiently control the interaction between tip leakage and passage secondary flows, and then reduce the total losses in turbines. Different types of axially uniform and non-uniform rotor tip clearances were used in this investigation, which include uniform, expanding, shrinking, and back- and front-step tip clearances. Based on the investigation of the interaction mechanism between tip leakage and passage secondary flows for different axially uniform tip clearance heights, the effects of axially non-uniform tip clearance on the aerodynamic performance of an unshrouded axial turbine at design and off-design conditions are presented and discussed in this article.

sec.title: 2 TIP GEOMETRY MODIFICATIONS
sec.p:
Blade tips are commonly at least partially damaged orworn in the course of operation. This may cause blade tip material to be lost or deformed, generally leading to the non-uniform change in tip geometry. In order to conveniently investigate the effect of axially non-uniform tip clearance on the turbine stage performance, typical rotor blade tip clearance shapes were considered, including uniform, expanding, shrinking, and back- and front-step tip clearances. Figure 1 shows a schematic of different axially non-uniform tip clearances, and the detailed definition of tip clearance chordwise distribution is given in Table 1. All the axially uniform and non-uniform tip clearances have the constant casing diameter 366 mm. In addition, all the axially non-uniform tip clearances have the same circumferential leakage area, and the average tip clearance is 2.6 per cent of the blade span (1.12 mm). Fig. 1
Schematic of different axially non-uniform tip clearances (left: leading edge) Table 1
Definition of tip clearance chordwise distribution
Tip clearance shapes Tip clearance/blade span (average tip clearance of 2.6%)
Tip clearance type Leading edge (%) Trailing edge (%) Step position
Uniform Linear 2.6 2.6 —
Expanding 2.17 3.04 —
Shrinking 3.04 2.17 —
Back-step Non-linear 2.33 3.26 70% Axial chord
Front-step 3.26 2.33 30% Axial chord

The blade chosen for this investigation is taken from the first-stage rotor blade in GE-E3 engines. The rotor blades are twisted, and have a constant axial chord length of 28.7 mm and an aspect ratio of 1.39. Detailed blade geometry and operating conditions can be found in the NASA report [23].

sec.title: 3 NUMERICAL TECHNIQUE
sec.p: The numerical investigation presented in this article was performed using the commercially available general flow solver ANSYS CFX 11.0 [24]. The governing equations were solved using a finite volume technique with a second-order upwind discretization scheme. A standard k-omega two-equation model [25] is used in this investigation for turbulence closure, and no wall functions are used.

The computational domain consisted of a single-blade channel with periodic boundary conditions imposed along the circumferential direction. Absolute total pressure and absolute total temperature are specified at the inlet along with the inlet flow angle and inlet turbulence intensity. Average static pressure is specified at the outlet. Solid surfaces are assumed to be adiabatic, and the no-slip condition is applied. Detailed boundary conditions are listed in Table 2. The inlet and exit of the computationaldomain are situated one and two axial chord lengths upstream and downstream of the rotor blade, respectively. Table 2
Boundary conditions
Parameters Values
Absolute total pressure ratio 2.25
69 ° Hub
Absolute inlet angle 74.5 ° Mid span
78.5 ° Shroud
Rotational speed 8450 r/min
Inlet turbulence intensity 5%

The commercial structured grid generation package Autogrid5 (preprocessor to NUMECA) was used in this investigation. Figure 2 shows a schematic of the blade geometry, and a typical grid used in the investigation. The channel was discretized into H-type grids, while the regions around blade surface and tip gap were discretized into O-type grids to improve grid quality. Furthermore, the grid was clustered near the leading and trailing edges, and near the tip region, with 33 spanwise grid points in the gap. Atotal of 187, 125, and 43 grid points were used alongthe axial, spanwise, and tangential directions, respectively. Fig. 2
Three-dimensional computational grid and details of the leading edge, trailing edge, and tip grids

Convergence criteria for these computations are based on the reduction of RMS residuals below 1 × 10−5. All results have been checked for convergence using isentropic efficiency (based on the total pressure and total temperature at the inlet and outlet of the rotor blade row) monitoring, and the solution was said to be converged when the isentropic efficiency was not changed more than 0.01 per cent during ten successive iterations. Nearly, 200 iterations were necessary for convergence.

The grid independency is checked by comparing all solutions of the baseline tip (1.12 mm) from three different grids, which are 0.81e6, 1.18e6, and 1.5e6 grid nodes. Blade loading distribution near the tips of all different grids is plotted, as shown in Fig. 3. It can be seen that the suction side static pressure at 0.81e6 grid nodes has a grid-dependent solution. When the grid nodes exceed 1.18e6, the solution becomes grid independent. In order to ensure solution validity and grid independence, a very refined grid (1.5e6 nodes) is used in this investigation. Fig. 3
Grid independency study of blade loading distribution near the tip

sec.title: 4 RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sec.p: The blade geometry and boundary conditions used for numerical simulations are the same as those used by Yang and Feng [26] and Ameri et al. [13] except for the wall boundary conditions. Yang and Feng [26] predicted the tip leakage flow and heat transfer by the CFX software. They also compared the numerical simulation with experimental data, and obtained a pretty reasonable computation quality; so did Ameri et al. [13]. Although no experimental data are available at this time, the authors’ experience and the information presented in this article show that the numerical simulation provides reliable information in investigating the effects of axially uniform and non-uniform rotor tip clearances.

The effects of axially uniform and non-uniform rotor tip clearances on the aerodynamic performance of the turbine rotors are discussed below, using the streamlines in the blade tip region, tip leakage loss development through the passage, tip static pressure coefficient distribution, blade loading near the tip at off-design conditions, and the relative change in tip leakage mass flow. Emphasis in the discussion is placed on the interaction mechanism between tip leakage and passage secondary flows (mainly the tip passage vortex).

sec.title: 4.1 Interaction of tip leakage vortex with the passage vortex for different axially uniform tip clearance heights
sec.p:
The dominating secondary flow phenomena in the rotor passage are the tip leakage and the passage vortexes. Figure 4 shows the streamlines in the blade tip region for different tip clearance heights. In order to make the readers clearly see the interaction process of tip leakage vortex with the passage vortex, streamlines are painted with the different colours to correspond with their axial locations in the gap. From Fig.4, it can be seen that, along the suction side, the flow field is very complex due to interactions of the tip leakage flow, passage secondary flow, and the relative motion of the casing. Fig. 4
Streamlines in the blade tip region for different tip clearance heights

In order to illustrate the tip clearance flows in turbine rotors, Fig. 4(e) is taken for a typical example. In Fig. 4(e), main flow attacking the gap at the front part of the pressure side is leading to a strong leakage flow. Some of the leakage flow through the gap, which does not roll into the tip leakage vortex, joins with the passage flow but still contributes to secondary flow effects inside rotor passage. It also can be seen that the tip leakage vortex is in the direction opposite to the passage vortex. In addition, a strong near-casing secondary flow towards the suction side of the passage is present, which is primarily caused by the relative motion of the casing, and acts to obstruct the leakage flow through the gap, particularly near the leading edge. Inside the rotor passage, the tip passagevortex (indicated by ‘TPV’) forms earlier due to the presence of a collateral boundary layer and the relative motion of the casing, and has been developed rapidly driven by the pressure difference between thepressure and the suction sides, leading to the tip leakage vortex’s formation later than the tip passage vortex (Lakshminarayana [3], Sjolander [5], DeCecco et al. [15], and McCarter et al. [27]).

Within a certain range of small clearance scale from 0.12 per cent to 0.58 per cent clearance, as shown inFig. 4(a), (b), and (c), a secondary flow towards the suction side of the rotor passage is present near the casing. This secondary flow resembles a passage vortex effect, which is primarily caused by the relative motion of the casing with respect to the rotor blade and its viscous shear layer. The tip leakage vortex (indicated by ‘TLV’) is so weak that the near-casing secondary flow near the leading edge enters the tip clearance region from the suction side, inhibiting the leakage flow, and then it is forced back out of the gap by the leakage flow further downstream from where it entered. As the flow moves downstream, the tip leakage vortex begins to form at the corner of suction side, and the passage vortex is gradually enhanced due to the entrainment of the low momentum fluid from the weak leakage vortex.

At the larger tip clearance scale from 1.16 per cent to 4.65 per cent clearance, as shown in Fig. 4(d), (e), and (f), the tip leakage vortex forms earlier, and acts as an obstruction to the counter-rotating passage vortex. Consequently, the passage secondary flow near the suction surface is forced underneath and to the side of the leakage vortex (Fig. 8), but to different extents for different tip clearance heights. As flow progresses downstream, the passage vortex is significantly weakened by its interaction with the tip leakage vortex, as these two have opposite senses of rotation. At the same time, the tip leakage vortex is slightly reduced in strength, but increased in size due to the greater entrainment of the passage vortex. Asimilar trend is seen in the measurement results presented by McCarter et al. [27].

The above analyses can also be proved from Fig. 5. In Fig. 5, a relatively low-pressure region dominates the blade suction surface near the tip, due to the tip leakage flow, and it is the trace of the tip leakage vortex left on the suction surface. Generally speaking, Figs 4 and 5 prove from two different aspects that the interaction mechanism between tip leakage and passage vortexes is different in the relatively small and large tip heights. Fig. 5
Static pressure coefficient distribution on the blade suction surfaces of the upper half, including the red isolines with Cps value of 0.34 (right: leading edge)

It also can be seen from Fig. 4 that, especially at the higher tip clearance height, the core of the leakagevortex is made up of fluid that passes through the gap from the leading edge and mid-chord regions and close to the blade tip. Other leakage flows through the gap wrap around the leakage vortex core, and do not have to roll up on their own. This finding further validates the same finding for low-speed turbine rotors by Tallman and Lakshminarayana [28].

Near the rotor blade trailing edge, the passage flow has been already well developed. Figure 6 shows entropy contours at 90 per cent axial chord for different tip clearance heights. With smaller tip clearanceheights, the high entropy losses are observed in the tip region, which are caused by the interaction of the passage vortex with the leakage vortex. The passage vortex entrains the low momentum fluid from the counter-rotating, weak leakage vortex causing it to mix further away from the blade resulting in much higher entropy losses in the passage vortex region. With the increase of the tip clearance height, the losses resulting from the tip passage vortex rapidly increase. For larger tip clearance heights, the passage vortex is broken down and is substantially weakened by the tip leakage vortex as the tip clearance height increases. Furthermore, at higher tip clearance height, the passage vortex is hardly visible at the 90 per cent axial chord. The high entropy loss region associated with the tip leakage vortex is greatly enhanced and transferred to the pressure side of adjacent rotor passage. Figure 7 shows the entropy contours at 110 per cent axial chord for different tip clearance heights. At this location downstream of the rotor blade, the tip leakage vortex, the wake, and the passage vortex fluid show strong turbulent mixing and diffusive character. However, it can be seen that Figs 6 and 7 show a similar trend. Fig. 6
Entropy contours at 90% axial chord for different tip clearance heights Fig. 7
Entropy contours at 110% axial chord for different tip clearance heights Fig. 8
Non-dimensional axial vorticity contours at20%, 50%, and 80% axial chords for the baseline tip

From the above analyses, it can be concluded that, with the moderate tip clearance height, the interaction between tip leakage vortex and passage vortex can be efficiently utilized to reduce the total losses in turbines. Here again, it can be further concluded that, in order to more efficiently control the interaction during the streamwise development, and then reduce the total losses throughout the rotor passage, axial non-uniform tip clearance concept can be introduced with the purpose of controlling the streamwise development of the tip leakage vortex, and thus weakening the adverse effects caused by the interaction of tip leakage vortex with the passage vortex.

sec.title: 4.2 Comparison of the performance between different axially non-uniform tip clearances
sec.p: The axial vorticity provides valuable insight into the nature of leakage and secondary flows. Figure 8 shows the non-dimensional axial vorticity contour plots at 20 per cent, 50 per cent, and 80 per cent axial chords for the baseline tip. Positive value indicates counterclockwise rotation. The non-dimensional axial vorticity is defined as follows (1) where vin, vx, and vy represent the inlet, radial, and circumferential velocities, and h the blade span. From Fig. 8, the interaction characteristics between tip leakage and passage vortexes can be clearly seen. As flow progresses downstream, the tip leakage vortex isgradually increased in size. The passage vortex is reduced in size as these two have opposite senses of rotation, and forced underneath and to the side of the leakage vortex.

In order to compare the performance between different axially non-uniform tip clearances, Fig. 9 shows the entropy contours near the blade tip at 20 per cent, 50 per cent, and 80 per cent axial chords and Fig. 10 shows the comparison of mass-averaged non-dimensional entropy increase at three locations shown in Fig. 9. In addition, the specific area chosen for the comparison of different axially non-uniform tip clearances is the area in the last 25 per cent of the blade height. Fig. 9
Entropy contours near the blade tip at 20%, 50%, and 80% axial chords for different axially non-uniform tip clearances Fig. 10
Comparison of mass-averaged non-dimensional entropy increase at 20%, 50%, and 80% axial chords, for different axially non-uniform tip clearances

From Figs 9 and 10, it can be seen that, in the front half of the blade, as discussed above, the passage vortex is rapidly developed within a short distance. For the shrink and front-step tip clearances, much more of the leakage flow due to the increased leakage area (Fig. 1) enters the gap. Inside the gap near the suction side, the near-casing secondary flow (Fig. 4(e)) acts as an obstruction to the leakage flow, which makes the interaction between the tip leakage and the passage vortexes to be efficiently utilized. As shown at the 50 per cent axial chord in Figs 9(c), (e) and 10, the efficient interaction reduces the strength of the tip leakage vortex and then the losses. For the expanding and back-step tip clearances, near the leading edge, due to the reduced leakage area (Fig.1), the tip leakage flow is so weak that the near-casing secondary flow entrains the more low momentum fluid from the leakage flow and its surrounding area (Fig. 4(a)). As the flow progresses downstream from the leading edge to the 50 per cent axial chord, the leakage vortex rapidly strengthens and causes great losses, due to the pressure difference between the pressure and the suction sides and the entrainment of the stronger passage vortex.

In the rear half of the blade, the strength of the leakage vortex is stronger than that of the passage vortex (McCarter et al. [27]). The shrink and front-step tip clearances provide a visible reduction in the area coverage of the tip leakage vortex, as shown at the 80 per cent axial chord. The reason is that the smaller tip clearance (Fig. 1) reduces the size and strength of the tip leakage vortex, and makes the passage vortex closer to the corner of suction side, reducing the high-loss region area. For the expanding and back-step tip clearances, the increased tip clearance (Fig. 1) increases the size of the tip leakage vortex. At the same time, the leakage vortex has been enhanced by the entrainment of the low momentum fluid from the weak passage vortex, and causes great losses.

In general, as shown in Figs 9 and 11, the front-step tip clearance produces the lower losses associated with a smaller size of the tip leakage vortex than the shrink tip clearance due to the more efficient interaction between the tip leakage and the passage vortexes, while the expanding tip clearance causes the slightly larger losses than the back-step tip clearance, which may be caused by the changes of the blade loading near the tip. This can also be confirmed by observing Figs 11, 12, and 13. Fig. 11
Streamlines through the gap for the uniform and front-step tip clearances Fig. 12
Static pressure coefficient contours at blade tip for different axially non-uniform tip clearances Fig. 13
Influence of different axially non-uniform tip clearances on tip leakage mass flow and isentropic efficiency

In order to effectively investigate the leakage flow inside the gap, the static pressure coefficient contours at blade tip for different axially non-uniform tip clearances are shown in Fig. 11. It shows that the zone near the leading edge does not have strong pressure gradients to result in significant tip leakage. The high level of over tip leakage flow occurs in between 40 per cent and 80 per cent axial chord regions. The last 20 per cent axial chord length region near the trailing edge experiences a relatively low tip leakage flow.

Zones near the leading edge are enlarged in the front-step tip clearance shown in Fig. 11(e), meaning that the pressure gradients are reduced in the front part of the blade tip and then the leakage flow is also reduced. However, the static pressure coefficient for other axially non-uniform tip clearances is changed a little in the front part of the blade tip.

The dominant tip leakage region of the front-step tip clearance is smaller than that of the uniform tipclearance. As a result of the smaller tip leakage dominant area, the mass flowrate of over tip leakage decreases. In addition, for the shrink tip clearance,thetip leakage region is slightly reduced. Forthe expanding and back-step tip clearances, the leakage region covers a wider area, and the low momentum fluid contained in this area generates a significant leakage flow into the suction side, especially for the expanding tip clearance.

The best approach to quantify the effectiveness of the axially non-uniform concept is to calculate the tip leakage mass flow and isentropic efficiency. Figure 13 compares the overall performance of the turbine rotors with different axially non-uniform tip clearances in more quantifiable terms. Tip leakage mass flow through the gap and isentropic efficiency are computed and compared. Tip leakage mass flow is reported as a percentage of the total turbine mass flow. It is clear that both shrink and front-step tip clearances provide a considerable gain in reducing tip leakage mass flow, especially the turbine rotor with front-step tip clearance attains the lowest tip leakage mass flow and the highest isentropic efficiency due to more efficient utilization of the interaction between tip leakage and passage secondary flows. However, the turbine rotors with the expandingand back-step tip clearances lead to an increase intip leakage mass flow. Furthermore, the expandingtip clearance has the maximum leakage massflow due to the deterioration of blade tip flow fields.

sec.title: 4.3 Effect of axially non-uniform tip clearance on the turbine performance at off-design conditions
sec.p:
In order to investigate the effect of axially non-uniform tip clearance on the turbine performance at off-design conditions, the turbine rotors are operated at three different rotational speeds marked by ‘NL (60 per cent ND), ND and NH (120 per cent ND)’, as shown in Fig. 14. The subscripts ‘L’, ‘D’, and ‘H’ represent low, design, and high rotational speeds. Figure 14 shows the blade loading near the tip at off-design conditions, for the uniform tip clearance. The blade loading is defined as follows (2) where Pp and Ps represent the static pressure at the pressure and the suction sides, respectively, and Pin * the inlet total pressure. Fig. 14
Blade loading near the tip at off-design conditions for the uniform tip clearance

It can be seen that, operating the turbine at off-conditions with different rotational speeds causes changes in blade incidence angle to the leading edge, and then has a strong impact on the loading distribution near the blade tip. With an increase in the rotational speed from low NL value (positive incidence angle) to high NH value (negative incidence angle), the total blade loading near the tip is slightly reduced, and the maximum loading position is moved from the leading edge to almost the 70 per cent axial chord.

The relative changes in tip leakage mass flow at off-design conditions for different axially non-uniform clearances are shown in Fig. 15. The turbine rotor with the front-step tip clearance is found to perform better than other axially non-uniform tip clearances at off-design conditions, which still has the lowest tip leakage mass flow. The leakage mass flow of the shrinking tip clearance decreases as the maximum loading location is moved downstream, likely due to the changed loading distribution near the blade tip and the slightly reduced loading. However, the leakage mass flow of the expanding and back-step tip clearances increase as the maximum loading location is moved downstream, despite the slightly reduced blade loading near the tip. Therefore, from the above analyses, it can be concluded that it will result in great losses when the maximum tip clearance and loading positions are in the same position along the blade. Fig. 15
Relative change in tip leakage mass flow at off-design conditions for different axially non-uniform clearances

sec.title: 5 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p:
An efficient numerical method has been employed toinvestigate the effect of axially non-uniform tip clearance on the aerodynamic performance of an unshrouded axial turbine at design and off-design conditions, in an attempt to seek an optimal tip clearance chordwise distribution to efficiently utilize the interaction between tip leakage and passage secondary flows, and then reduce the total losses in turbines. Some of the important conclusions based on the investigation presented in this article are summarized as follows.
For the axially uniform tip clearances, the interaction mechanism between tip leakage and secondary flows is different in the relatively small and large tip clearance heights. With the moderate tip clearance height, the interaction between tip leakage and passage vortexes can be efficiently utilized to reduce the total losses in turbines.
For the turbine rotors with different axially non-uniform tip clearances, the turbine rotor with the front-step tip clearance can attain the highest isentropic efficiency, because of more efficient utilization of the interaction between tip leakage and passage secondary flows throughout the rotor passage.
Operating conditions have a strong impact on the performance of the turbine rotors with the axially non-uniform tip clearance. Despite the fact that it will result in great losses when the maximum tip clearance and loading positions are in the same position along the blade, the off-design point performance of the turbine can be improved to a greater extent, by means of the proper design of the tip clearance shape.
Since the leakage and passage vortexes have a significant interaction in the rotor passage, and the rest of the passage is affected from this interaction, how to efficiently utilize the interaction and then reduce the adverse effects due to the secondary flows is a practical way for improving the turbine performance.
